body.header: Read the report on the water-balanced railway again. What do the highlighted cohesive devices in the text refer to?

ol.li:
What does 'which' refer to?
the carriage
the ballast tank
the water-balanced railway

What does 'These' refer to?
the steel tracks
the carriages
the steel cables

What does 'it' refer to?
the ballast tank
the top carriage
the reservoir

What does 'the other one' refer to?
the lower carriage
the higher carriage
the imbalance

What does 'them' refer to?
the carriages
the steel tracks
the steel cables

What does 'This' refer to
the drum
the braking system
the computer system

What does 'which' refer to?
the hydraulic pump
the braking system
the computer system

What does 'it' refer to?
the braking system
the hydraulic pump
the drum

What does 'this' refer to?
the carriages reduce speed
the braking system
the gas is compressed

What does 'This' refer to?
the braking system
the hydraulic pump
the stored energy

p.font: 1A: Although the carriage does carry water, as well as passengers, the pronoun here refers to something else.
1C: This is the whole system, so the pronoun can't refer to this.
2A: If you look at the diagram you'll see that the tracks don't go around the drum.
2B: The diagram shows that the carriages only go up and down. They can't go around the drum.
3A: The ballast tank itself doesn't have to be heavier than the other carriage. The weight of the carriage, ballast and passengers altogether is what's important.
4B: Can the higher one be pulled up?
5C: The cables aren't mentioned in this, or the previous exercise.
6A: The drum is a simple component in the system. It doesn't 'consist of' anything; it houses the breaking system.
6C: The computer system doesn't 'consist of' a pump; it controls the pump.
7: 'which' refers to the noun immediately before the comma in this sentence.
8: Look at the verb associated with the pronoun. Can the braking system 'turn'?
9B: Look at the verb associated with the pronoun. Can the braking system 'happen'?
9C: This is the result. What happens to compress the gas?
10: Look back to the previous sentence to see what the pronoun refers to.

section.p: Cohesive devices are words and phrases that can be used to refer back or forward to other words and ideas in a text. Good writers use them to make their writing clearer, more organized and more logical. Such devices include linking words and phrase like those we looked at in the earlier exercises. Pronouns such as 'which', 'it', 'this', 'that', and 'they' are other examples of cohesive devices.
The water-balanced railway basically operates like a huge balance, using the difference in weight between the two carriages to transport passengers up and down a hillside 30 metres in height.

The carriages are made of timber and steel so that they are light and strong. Underneath each one is a ballast tank, (1) which carries up to 1600 litres of water. The carriages run along 53 metres of parallel steel track and are linked by steel cables. (2) These go around a large drum at the top of the slope.

When one carriage is at the top of the hill, the other is at the bottom. The ballast tank underneath the top carriage is filled with water from a reservoir so as to make (3) it slightly heavier than the lower carriage. Due to this imbalance, the top one begins to roll down the hill, pulling (4) the other one up. A computer control system weighs each carriage in order to gauge exactly how much water is needed to make (5) them move. Speed is controlled by means of a braking system built into the drum at the top. (6) This consists of a hydraulic pump, (7) which slows the drum down if (8) it is turning too fast, causing the carriages to reduce speed. Each time (9) this happens, the system compresses gas in special cylinders. As a result, some of the energy of braking is stored. (10) This can later be used to pump a proportion of the water back up to the reservoir. Consequently, some energy is recycled.
The water-balanced railway is an excellent example of how renewable energy sources can be used to power a transport system.
